title: Are there people over 50 who still read Stephen King? - Quora

response.answer_text: I'm one. I read *Under the Dome* and found it a. too long b. too political. He still has his town and character-building chops. It's an OK book, not his best. The same is true of his *11/22/63, * though I felt the consequences of the alternate timeline were plain silly, even a copout historically. (No spoilers!) He can write a mystery series. So the answer is: yes.

Stephen King is 72 so it’s highly likely his main audience is over 50. People grew up with his writings and the fact that he’s sold over 350,000,000 books and is responsible for 84 movies must mean that he’s doing something exceptional to garner such a large audience. I read him because he is an excellent writer and has a active imagination. My only complaint with his work is that IMO often the endings don’t equal the beginnings and the majority of the ensuing prose.

I’m 67. I’ve been reading King since Carrie came out in 1974. I even wrote him a letter and have his reply. He was still able to reply to fan mail at hat point. He’s an extraordinary and sadly underrated writer. Academia hates him. But then again, they don’t have his talent.

I have personally almost completely stopped reading him. I’ve just tired of his writing style, at least in novels. However, some of his short stories are masterful, and I do want to read his recent collections, sometime. I would assume that most of his readers are over 50 years old, to be honest.
Well, I’m over 50, but I’m not a fan of the horror genre, so I never read a lot of his stuff even when I was younger—I do like some of his non-horror books, such as The Dark Tower.
